Description: Roman discus lamp, with a fine glossy red-brown slip. Plain rim with a crescent-like projection on each side of the plain discus. Remains of vertical, pierced, grooved handle. Fine red fabric with white inclusions. Broken handle.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, Philadelphia. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallel from Roman Ehnasya (Petrie 1905, 7, pl. 57.Q32; Corinth IV.2, pl. 10.473 type 24) cited on Philadelphia register card. Marked in ink '113'. variants of the Loeschcke Type VIII discus lamp made in Egypt with ornamental side lug projections from the discus are in the British Museum, dated 2nd to 3rd century AD (Bailey 1988, nos Q2080-1). Petrie, W.M.Fl. 1905. Roman Ehnasya (Herakleopolis Magna), 1904. London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KE.25) (Phase 1)
